reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as いい加減, which you (hopefully) learned earlier.

The readings are the kun'yomi readings. Why? Because this word is really two separate words connected together into one bigger word. You know the kun'yomi readings from vocab practice in previous levels.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as 乱れる, so hopefully you know it already.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
You say you have something you need <vocabulary>to plan</vocabulary>? <reading>Coo</reading>l, <reading>whadda</reading>ya (くわだ) gonna do?
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
判 is the reading you learned. 子 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which I bet you know pretty well by now as well. You just have to remember to use it here.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is a little weird. It's double kun'yomi where the 刺す becomes stem form and gets pushed inside the kanji to become さし. The 身 is just the word 身's reading.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

<vocabulary>To work as</vocabulary> my secretary, you will have to complete a task. A task where you bring me <reading>two toe</reading>s (つと)! Don't ask me why! You want <vocabulary>to serve as</vocabulary> my assistant, right? Just get me those two toes then!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the reading of 参加.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading for 反 is all good. The reading for 省 is an on'yomi reading you haven't seen yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

I'm standing in front of you, forcing a <vocabulary>reconsideration</vocabulary> of your anti conserve stance, with my <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) to your throat. I better see some reflection on your face or you won't have one in a second.

The reading is the kun'yomi readings put together. Thank 口 for being a body part, which tends to cause this to happen. So, you have 口 (くち) and 笛 (ふえ) put together, though ふえ changes to ぶえ, maybe because you can't whistle properly? Buuuweeee. Buwwweee.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 名詞 as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings come from 埋める and 合わせる. Combine them into one big happy word.
It would be <reading>foo</reading>lish (ふ) of you to touch anything while things are increasing anyways. You don't want to mess up a good thing, do you? Don't be a fool.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Let's continue the previous story: You're off in the <vocabulary>extremity</vocabulary> of space and your friend is running low on Vitamin D. He <reading>has</reading> (はず) to get some sun れs on his skin! How's that supposed to happen with those spacesuits on, though?

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Both kanji have a couple different on'yomi readings though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to pick:

Your <vocabulary>arch enemy</vocabulary> is the <reading>tie techie</reading> (たいてき). Who's the tie techie? He's the tech support guy at work who always wears the same tie and never helps you. He just says "try restarting your computer" to every problem, which isn't helpful. He's not just a great enemy, he's basically your nemesis. You hate that tie techie.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help to know how to read the word 宇宙 on its own, too.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 宇宙 beforehand as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The つ is shortened to っ.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to be able to read 容疑 first, though.
The reading is that of 履く and 物 put together. Just know those separately and you should be able to figure this one out as well.
The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the first two kanji. Luckily you learned them when you learned the kanji. Then, stick 県 on there and you should be good to go!
The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, you've learned them both already!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 形容詞 and 動詞 as well, since they're both parts of this word.
The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of 手 and 続く put together into one. Darn these body parts making everything kun'yomi.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The reading for this is the same as the other "to rise" word, 上がる. Nice how that works, right? So, just associate the two and you have yourself a reading.

The main reading is the same one you learned with the kanji. But there's also a secondary かたき reading you haven't seen yet, so here's a mnemonic for that:

You love to call your <vocabulary>enemy</vocabulary>'s <reading>car tacky</reading> (かたき). They're always driving around in some tacky sports car, you can't stand it. Every time they drive by you shout, "Your car is tacky, enemy!"

Note: In terms of differences, the てき reading just means "enemy," whereas かたき typically refers to someone you hold a deep grudge against, often on behalf of another.

Deciding <vocabulary>to refuse</vocabulary> something unfortunately starts a <reading>coat war</reading> (like a pillow fight, but everyone hits each other with coats instead of pillows). Coats to the ready, and let the coat war commence!

The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, though て goes to で.
The reading is the same as 混乱 so no reason for you <vocabulary>to be confused</vocabulary>, right?

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your romp finally has <vocabulary>to come to an end</vocabulary> when someone decides to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you for all your romping.
The reading is the same as 減る, so if you know that reading you should know this one.
This word uses the kun'yomi, which you already learned when you learned the word 無し.

You know another "to give birth" word (生む). Guess what!? They share readings!

The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven’t learned this reading for 覚 yet, and in this case it also gets rendaku’d, so bear that in mind. Anyway, here’s a mnemonic to help you:

If you start <vocabulary>to wake up</vocabulary> in the middle of the night, it’s because of the <reading>Czar</reading> (ざ) you met that had banned sitting. This cruel, ruthless Czar keeps appearing in your nightmares, causing you to wake up incessantly. Terrifying.
You <reading>have</reading> (はぶ) what you have, and omit what you don't need. Perfect life.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You gotta pray for Christmas presents if you want Santa to bring you some!" "<reading>I know</reading> (いの), I know," you reply as you begin to pray for presents. You should say this out loud to remember it better.

This combines the readings of two verbs you already know, so you should be good to go here!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The りつ shortens to りっ though, so keep an eye on that you splendid frood you. Oh and は changes to ぱ too. Because rendaku and all that.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 素 is the そ reading, so be careful. You can remember by thinking how you have to <reading>sew</reading> the building together using these raw materials.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The さい changes to ざい, though, so watch out for that.
The reading is the same as 続く, so be sure to know that so you can know this.

You're really starting <vocabulary>to envy</vocabulary> those <reading>ura</reading>nium <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (うらや). That's the new Yankees team hopped up on uranium that were created in a lab. Even though they're gross and hulk-ish, they're really good at baseball, so you're jealous of them.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

You don’t just get irritated, you get <reading>ira-ira</reading>-tated (いらいら). That's the next level up from irritated.

This word is often written in katakana or hiragana, but you'll sometimes see it in kanji too, so it's worth knowing!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

While you're sitting there with no cares, waiting for things <vocabulary>to be solved</vocabulary>, you stare down at your <reading>toe</reading> (と). Really imagine looking at your toe while things around you are getting solved.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

What are you going <vocabulary>to establish</vocabulary>? How about a system for <reading>mow</reading>ing (もう) lawns? It's very important that lawns are mowed according to an established system, you know. How do you mow yours?
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful because the 設 gets shortened to せっ.

The only thing you could ever truly <vocabulary>acknowledge</vocabulary> is <reading>meat</reading> (みと). Meat is the only thing in your life that has any authority over you. That's how much you love meat.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also immensely help to know the reading of the word 説得.

You're on the very <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> of the world. You heard that at the edge of the world are the <reading>key wo</reading>rds (きわ) written there in big fiery letters, telling you the meaning of life. Supposedly these are the words of God himself. They say: "We apologize for the inconvenience." WHAT? THESE ARE THE <reading>KEY WO</reading>RDS???

Note that this word is often written in kana, as きわ or キワ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
